line: MODERNIZING GOVERNMENT
label: heading

line: FOR THE 21ST CENTURY
label: heading

line: WHERE WE ARE: FEDERAL CONTEXT
label: heading

line: When America’s Founders established the
label: paragraph

line: Constitution, they laid out a clear mission for the
label: paragraph

line: Federal Government, from providing for the com-
label: paragraph

line: mon defense to securing the blessings of liberty.
label: paragraph

line: To this day, the business of Government remains
label: paragraph

line: to serve the American people by meeting their ex-
label: paragraph

line: pectations in these foundational mission areas.
label: paragraph

line: Nearly two decades into the 21st Century, the
label: paragraph

line: public still believes that the Federal Government
label: paragraph

line: serves critical roles and, in some areas, does
label: paragraph

line: them well.1 Yet public trust in the Federal
label: paragraph

line: Government continues to decline, sitting at near-
label: paragraph

line: historic lows.2 The Nation faces a significant
label: paragraph

line: national debt and annual deficits that require
label: paragraph

line: Government to change how it operates.
label: paragraph

line: HOW WE GOT HERE: ROOT CAUSE
label: heading

line: CHALLENGES AND EFFECTS
label: heading

line: Many of the Federal Government’s challenges
label: paragraph

line: and shortcomings arise from practices designed
label: paragraph

line: in the past and trends that can no longer be sus-
label: paragraph

line: tained. Major root cause challenges facing the
label: paragraph

line: Federal Government include:
label: paragraph

line: Accumulated Regulatory Burden. Over
label: paragraph

line: many decades, Federal agencies have imposed
label: paragraph

line: countless regulatory requirements on individu-
label: paragraph

line: als, businesses, landowners, and State and local
label: paragraph

line: governments. Some of these regulations serve
label: paragraph

line: important public purposes. Many regulations,
label: paragraph

line: however, are outdated, duplicative, or unnec-
label: paragraph

line: essary, yet continue to impose costly burdens.
label: paragraph

line: 1 Pew Research Center, December 2017, “Government Gets Lower
label: paragraph

line: Ratings for Handling Health Care, Environment, Disaster Re-
label: paragraph

line: sponse.”
label: paragraph

line: 2 Pew Research Center, May 2017, “Public Trust in Government
label: paragraph

line: Remains Near Historic Lows as Partisan Attitudes Shift.”
label: paragraph

line: Careful reconsideration of the regulatory burden
label: paragraph

line: is necessary to promote economic growth and in-
label: paragraph

line: dividual freedom.
label: paragraph

line: Structural Issues. Silos across Federal agen-
label: paragraph

line: cies and offices can stymie collaboration, result-
label: paragraph

line: ing in fragmented services and piecemeal efforts.
label: paragraph

line: Greater coordination is needed among and with-
label: paragraph

line: in agencies and also with the Congress to im-
label: paragraph

line: prove management of the Federal Government
label: paragraph

line: and to remove outdated
label: paragraph

line: obstacles to change.
label: paragraph

line: regulations and other
label: paragraph

line: Decision-Making and Processes. The pub-
label: paragraph

line: lic lacks sufficient opportunities to give feed-
label: paragraph

line: back on Federal programs and services, making
label: paragraph

line: it harder to identify weaknesses and make im-
label: paragraph

line: provements. Smarter use of data and evidence
label: paragraph

line: is needed to orient decisions and accountability
label: paragraph

line: around service and results.
label: paragraph

line: Leadership and Culture. Achieving benefi-
label: paragraph

line: cial outcomes that serve the public should be the
label: paragraph

line: Federal Government’s primary focus. Yet service
label: paragraph

line: delivery sometimes suffers due to checking un-
label: paragraph

line: necessary bureaucratic boxes. Managers need
label: paragraph

line: greater discretion to execute programs effective-
label: paragraph

line: ly, foster the highest-performing workforce, and
label: paragraph

line: solve real-time problems.
label: paragraph

line: Capabilities and Competencies. Antiqua-
label: paragraph

line: ted, unsecure technology risks can leave the pub-
label: paragraph

line: lic frustrated and vulnerable. Too many Federal
label: paragraph

line: employees perform outdated duties that rely on
label: paragraph

line: outdated skillsets, and Government too often
label: paragraph

line: struggles to award effective, timely contracts. A
label: paragraph

line: more nimble and effective approach is needed to
label: paragraph

line: keep technologies and workforce skills current
label: paragraph

line: and to ensure that
label: paragraph

line: meet future needs.
label: paragraph

line: GENERATIONAL VISION FOR REFORM
label: heading

line: The vision for reform must be multi-gener-
label: paragraph

line: ational, enabling the Federal Government to
label: paragraph

line: continue adapting to changing needs over time.
label: paragraph

line: The Administration cannot pursue short-term
label: paragraph

line: ers will determine the Administration’s success
label: paragraph

line: at reform. Modernizing and strengthening these
label: paragraph

line: drivers will bolster results
label: paragraph

line: agencies and mission areas.
label: paragraph

line: throughout Federal
label: paragraph

line: fixes only to see Government quickly become
label: paragraph

line: outdated once again. Deep-seated transforma-
label: paragraph

line: tion takes time and will not happen in one or
label: paragraph

line: two years.
label: paragraph

line: In March, the Administration will announce
label: paragraph

line: the President’s Management Agenda, which
label: paragraph

line: will set forth a long-term vision for an effective
label: paragraph

line: Government that works on behalf of the American
label: paragraph

line: people and is focused on the following:
label: paragraph

line: Mission: The American people count on the
label: paragraph

line: Federal Government every day, from national se-
label: paragraph

line: curity to infrastructure to food and water safety.
label: paragraph

line: Public servants must be accountable for mission-
label: paragraph

line: driven results and have the necessary tools to
label: paragraph

line: deliver.
label: paragraph

line: Service: Federal customers range from small
label: paragraph

line: businesses seeking loans, to families receiving di-
label: paragraph

line: saster support, to veterans owed proper benefits
label: paragraph

line: and medical care. They deserve a customer ex-
label: paragraph

line: perience that compares to—or exceeds—that of
label: paragraph

line: leading private organizations.
label: paragraph

line: Stewardship: Effective stewardship of tax-
label: paragraph

line: payer funds is a crucial responsibility, from pre-
label: paragraph

line: venting fraud to maximizing impact. Taxpayer
label: paragraph

line: dollars must go to effective programs that ef-
label: paragraph

line: ficiently produce results. The Budget conserva-
label: paragraph

line: tively projects that $139 billion in savings can be
label: paragraph

line: achieved over the next decade through the pre-
label: paragraph

line: vention of improper payments alone.
label: paragraph

line: HOW WE WILL GET THERE: KEY
label: heading

line: DRIVERS OF REFORM
label: heading

line: The Federal Government’s challenges have not
label: paragraph

line: arisen in isolation, and cannot be solved through
label: paragraph

line: isolated efforts. The Administration will drive
label: paragraph

line: Government modernization by working at the
label: paragraph

line: junctions where these
label: paragraph

line: than working in silos.
label: paragraph

line: drivers intersect, rather
label: paragraph

line: Over time, it will target
label: paragraph

line: broad impacts on underlying issues, including
label: paragraph

line: legislative changes.
label: paragraph

line: Modern information technology will func-
label: paragraph

line: tion as the backbone of how Government serves
label: paragraph

line: the public in ways that meet their expectations
label: paragraph

line: and keep sensitive data and systems secure.
label: paragraph

line: Data, accountability, and transparency
label: paragraph

line: will provide the tools to deliver visibly better re-
label: paragraph

line: sults to the public and hold agencies accountable
label: paragraph

line: to taxpayers.
label: paragraph

line: A modern workforce will enable senior lead-
label: paragraph

line: ers and front line managers to align staff skills
label: paragraph

line: with evolving mission needs. This will require
label: paragraph

line: more nimble and agile management of the work-
label: paragraph

line: force, including reskilling and redeploying exist-
label: paragraph

line: ing workers to keep pace with an environment of
label: paragraph

line: change.
label: paragraph

line: FROM VISION TO ACTION: COMMITMENTS

label: paragraph

line: effective, and accountable. The Administration
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: tiple channels that, together, will yield tangible

line: Reorganization and Reform. Last March, the
label: paragraph

line: President sent out a call for change in Executive
label: paragraph

line: Order 13781, “Comprehensive Plan for Reorganizing
label: paragraph

line: the Executive Branch,” where he tasked the Office of
label: paragraph

line: Management and Budget (OMB) Director with pro-
label: paragraph

line: viding a plan to reorganize the Executive Branch.
label: paragraph

line: The Budget is a first step in presenting this plan to
label: paragraph

line: the American people. This plan includes changes
label: paragraph

line: that can be accomplished with existing authorities
label: paragraph

line: as well as others that would require new funding
label: paragraph

line: and authorities. These changes also include re-
label: paragraph

line: forms identified by individual Federal employees,
label: paragraph

line: who answered the Administration’s request for
label: paragraph

line: their best ideas to improve public services or better
label: paragraph

line: use taxpayer dollars.
label: paragraph

line: nating unnecessary political positions; using
label: paragraph

line: shared services to improve IT services and
label: paragraph

line: reduce costs through economies of scale; re-
label: paragraph

line: aligning offices and personnel; and revamping
label: paragraph

line: regional offices. For instance, in order to im-
label: paragraph

line: prove customer service, the Department of the
label: paragraph

line: Interior has already begun to shift employees
label: paragraph

line: away from Washington, District of Columbia,
label: paragraph

line: closer to the citizens the Agency serves. The
label: paragraph

line: Department of Energy is also planning to re-
label: paragraph

line: view its existing laboratory network and iden-
label: paragraph

line: tify potential efficiencies.
label: paragraph

line: planning to review how it can restructure func-
label: paragraph

line: tions across Federal agencies. For instance, it
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: Investment Corporation

line: Getting Government Out of the Way. Within
label: paragraph

line: 10 days of taking office, the President issued
label: paragraph

line: Executive Order 13771, “Reducing Regulation
label: paragraph

line: and Controlling Regulatory Costs,” which directs
label: paragraph

line: agencies to reduce regulatory burdens by elimi-
label: paragraph

line: nating two existing regulations for each new one
label: paragraph

line: issued and impose no net regulatory burden in
label: paragraph

line: The Administration recognizes that excessive
label: paragraph

line: and unnecessary Federal regulations limit in-
label: paragraph

line: dividual freedom and suppress the innovation
label: paragraph

line: BUDGET OF THE U. S. GOVERNMENT FOR FISCAL YEAR 2019
label: paragraph

line: and entrepreneurship that make America great.
label: paragraph

line: Starting with confidence in private markets and
label: paragraph

line: individual choices, this Administration is reas-
label: paragraph

line: sessing existing regulatory burdens. Agencies
label: paragraph

line: have identified regulatory actions ripe for reform
label: paragraph

line: and are working to eliminate or modify those re-
label: paragraph

line: quirements. The Administration also approaches
label: paragraph

line: the imposition of new regulatory requirements
label: paragraph

line: with caution to ensure that regulations are con-
label: paragraph

line: sistent with law, necessary to correct a substantial
label: paragraph

line: market failure, and net beneficial to the public.
label: paragraph

line: The Administration’s regulatory philosophy
label: paragraph

line: and approach emphasize the connection between
label: paragraph

line: limited Government intervention and individ-
label: paragraph

line: ual liberty. Regulatory policy should serve the
label: paragraph

line: American people by staying within legal limits
label: paragraph

line: and administering the law with respect for due
label: paragraph

line: process and fair notice.
label: paragraph

line: In December 2017, OMB released its
label: paragraph

line: Regulatory Reform Status Report: Two-for-One
label: paragraph

line: and Regulatory Cost Maps, which assessed agen-
label: paragraph

line: cy performance under Executive Order 13771
label: paragraph

line: during 2017. At the same time, OMB released the
label: paragraph

line: Unified Agenda of Regulatory and Deregulatory
label: paragraph

line: Actions and the Regulatory Plan, which set forth
label: paragraph

line: the Administration’s roadmap for a more limited,
label: paragraph

line: effective, and accountable
label: paragraph

line: 2018 and beyond.
label: paragraph

line: regulatory policy in
label: paragraph

line: Regulatory Reform in 2017. In just
label: paragraph

line: its first eight months, the Administration
label: paragraph

line: eliminated 67 regulations and adopted
label: paragraph

line: only three significant new regulations.
label: paragraph

line: This 22-to-one ratio far exceeds the
label: paragraph

line: President’s “two-for-one” requirement. It
label: paragraph

line: also generated $8.1 billion in net regu-
label: paragraph

line: latory cost savings (present value), far
label: paragraph

line: surpassing the President’s requirement to
label: paragraph

line: hold net costs to zero. The Administration
label: paragraph

line: took further action to withdraw or delay
label: paragraph

line: more than 1,500 regulations in the pipe-
label: paragraph

line: line, and has been transparent about these
label: paragraph

line: planned regulatory actions. This pace and
label: paragraph

line: scope of deregulation is unprecedented.
label: paragraph

line: Regulatory Reform in 2018 and
label: paragraph

line: Beyond. The Administration’s Unified
label: paragraph

line: Agenda currently projects the elimination
label: paragraph

line: of approximately 448 regulations and the
label: paragraph

line: addition of only 131 new regulations. In
label: paragraph

line: 2018, Federal agencies are committed to
label: paragraph

line: cutting more than $9.8 billion in lifetime
label: paragraph

line: regulatory costs. Across the Government,
label: paragraph

line: this Agenda will drive substantial reduc-
label: paragraph

line: tions in regulatory costs beyond what has
label: paragraph

line: already been accomplished. For additional
label: paragraph

line: information, please visit www.reginfo.gov.
label: paragraph

line: At its core, regulatory reform not only pro-
label: paragraph

line: motes individual liberty and a flourishing econ-
label: paragraph

line: omy, but also supports America’s constitutional
label: paragraph

line: democracy. OMB’s regulatory review process
label: paragraph

line: ensures that agencies stay within the legal au-
label: paragraph

line: thority given by the Congress. Where the law
label: paragraph

line: leaves discretion, however, the Administration
label: paragraph

line: will work with agencies to ensure that regula-
label: paragraph

line: tory policy reflects Presidential priorities. This
label: paragraph

line: executive direction grounds the rulemaking
label: paragraph

line: process in democratic accountability.
label: paragraph

line: By starting from a foundation of confidence
label: paragraph

line: in markets, individual choice, and the hard-
label: paragraph

line: working men and women of America, the
label: paragraph

line: Administration has already achieved—and will
label: paragraph

line: continue to achieve—dramatic reductions in
label: paragraph

line: the regulatory burden on the American econo-
label: paragraph

line: my and individual freedom. The agenda for the
label: paragraph

line: coming year promises a regulatory policy that
label: paragraph

line: works for the American people.
label: paragraph

line: A Clear Roadmap Ahead. The Federal
label: paragraph

line: Government cannot be fully equipped to meet
label: paragraph

line: modern management challenges without sup-
label: paragraph

line: port from the Congress. In some cases, real
label: paragraph

line: change will demand different agency struc-
label: paragraph

line: tures. In other cases, the Administration may
label: paragraph

line: need to update rigid requirements from the
label: paragraph

line: past that hold back Government.
label: paragraph

line: Government must recognize that it can no
label: paragraph

line: longer meet modern needs with the same ap-
label: paragraph

line: proaches, technology, and skillsets from cen-
label: paragraph

line: turies past. By acknowledging shortcomings,
label: paragraph

line: setting a modern vision, and delivering on
label: paragraph

line: concrete goals, the Administration can adapt
label: paragraph

line: Federal programs, capabilities, and the Federal
label: paragraph

line: workforce to more efficiently, effectively and
label: paragraph

line: accountably meet mission demands and public
label: paragraph

line: expectations.
